Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the step-parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Story: I stared at the text from my acquaintance, asking if I could help move some boxes this weekend. He’d helped me once before, so I felt obligated to return the favor. At the same time, I glanced at the note on the fridge: “Don’t forget the Nintendo for Jamie’s birthday!” My partner and I had promised Jamie, my stepchild, that we’d get it this year, and I knew how much it meant to them. But money was tight, and I’d planned to pick up extra shifts to cover the cost. If I helped my acquaintance, I’d have to skip those shifts, making the Nintendo purchase nearly impossible. I felt the weight of both expectations pressing down on me—Jamie’s hopeful eyes, my partner’s trust, and my acquaintance’s reliance. My stomach twisted as I tried to figure out how to be the dependable step-parent and the supportive friend at the same time, knowing I couldn’t fully satisfy both.
